status_message:
"When my brother was killed, it changed everything."

In November 2008, Marcelo Lucero was attacked and killed in a racially motivated crime in Patchogue, on New York's Long Island. For Marcelo's brother Jose, things have never been the same. 

Listen to United States of Anxiety from WNYC and The Nation Magazine. https://www.thenation.com/article/the-media-that-created-trump/
link_name: "When my brother was killed, it changed everything."

status_message:
How responsible is the media for calling out a candidate's untruths? Has the media employed a double-standard in reporting on Hillary Clinton's candidacy? What role has gender played? How have different media shaped (and misshaped) the campaign? What lessons should we draw from media coverage of this election? What changes need to be considered? What is the role of media in a democracy?

Join the conversation with a deeply engaged panel of political and media analysts one week before the most important election of our lifetimes. Admission free but RSVP required. 

Welcome: Mary Watson
Introduction: Katrina vanden Heuvel
Speakers: Joan Walsh, Farai Chideya, Katha Pollitt, Rinku Sen 
Moderator: Laura Flanders

Sponsored by The New School.
link_name: Media Malpractice and Election 2016

status_message:
Legendary civil rights leader Jesse Jackson made history in his 1984 and 1988 presidential campaigns, in which he won 18 state contests and millions of votes, making him the first viable African-American candidate for President of the United States.

Jackson has been on the outside and the inside, protesting and leading, at every Democratic convention over the past 50 years. The Nation's chief political writer, John Nichols, will interview Jackson, with an introduction from Nation editor and publisher, Katrina vanden Heuvel. Audience questions will follow. 

This event is free and open to the public. Advance registration required. Seating available on a first come, first served basis. Sponsored by The Nation. Co-sponsored by Progressive Democrats of America.
link_name: 50 Years On: A Conversation with Jesse Jackson

status_message: Damn: "Why should they ask me to put on a uniform and go 10,000 miles from home and drop bombs and bullets on Brown people in Vietnam while so-called Negro people in Louisville are treated like dogs and denied simple human rights? No I'm not going 10,000 miles from home to help murder and burn another poor nation simply to continue the domination of white slave masters of the darker people the world over. This is the day when such evils must come to an end. I have been warned that to take such a stand would cost me millions of dollars. But I have said it once and I will say it again. The real enemy of my people is here. I will not disgrace my religion, my people or myself by becoming a tool to enslave those who are fighting for their own justice, freedom and equality…. If I thought the war was going to bring freedom and equality to 22 million of my people they wouldn't have to draft me, I'd join tomorrow. I have nothing to lose by standing up for my beliefs. So I'll go to jail, so what? We've been in jail for 400 years."
link_name: 'I Just Wanted to Be Free': The Radical Reverberations of Muhammad Ali

status_message: In 1942, 21-year-old Rosanell Eaton took a two-hour mule ride to the Franklin County courthouse in eastern North Carolina to register to vote. The three white male registrars told her to stand up straight, with her arms at her side, look straight ahead and recite the preamble to the Constitution from memory. After she did that word for word, they gave her a written literacy test, which she also passed.

status_message:
Join The Nation magazine's award-winning sportswriter, Dave Zirin, for a hard-hitting conversation about race, gender, politics and sports with the man called "the best sportswriter in the United States," by the legendary Robert Lipsyte. 

*Have professional sports helped break down race barriers, or helped the wealthy, white elite to profit by exploiting people of color? 
*How do athletes perpetuate gender stereotypes or challenge them?
*What is the future of sports in a world with a disappearing middle class, a growing awareness that all lives matter, and a shifting gender consciousness? 
*How can sports promote a social justice agenda? 

Come prepared to share your love of the game--and to ask the tough questions, together with journalist, UW lecturer, and host of the evening, Caley Cook.
 
This event is brought to you by the UW Department of Communication and co-sponsored by the UW Center for Human Rights as part of The Nation's 150th anniversary event tour.

For a complete lineup of events across the country throughout 2015, visit thenation.com/events.
link_name: Race, Power, Jock Culture: A Conversation With Dave Zirin

status_message:
The Nation at the Brooklyn Book Festival!

2015 marks the 150th anniversary of The Nation magazine. The story of The Nation is also the story of America's hidden history of resistance and struggle against racial discrimination, economic injustice and intolerance. 

Join a conversation about The Nation and the social change movements it has long chronicled with: 
*Katrina vanden Heuvel - editor & publisher of The Nation
*Greg Grandin - professor, NYU & author of "Kissinger's Shadow: The Long Reach of America's Most Controversial Statesman"
*Patricia J. Williams - professor, Columbia University & author of "The Blind Goddess: A Reader on Race and Justice"
*Chris Hayes - host, MSNBC & author of "Twilight of the Elites"

This event is free & open to the public. More information at: http://www.brooklynbookfestival.org/2015-festival-events/the-nation-at-150

Book signings by all four speakers will follow the conversation!
link_name: Brooklyn Book Festival: The Nation at 150

status_message:
In honor of The Nation magazine's 150th anniversary, Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto—creators of The Nation's weekly crossword puzzle—will host an evening of specially-created word games and puzzles.

Online ticket sales have ended but tickets will be available at the door for $10. Admission includes a copy of The Nation's special sesquicentennial collectors issue.

Joshual and Henri will pose a variety of puzzles and games, which attendees can tackle competitively or collaboratively. Prizes will go to the most accomplished puzzlers, and to the luckiest.

The evening will feature an introduction to cryptic crosswords, including solving an as-yet unpublished Nation crossword puzzle together with the entire group. This will offer newbies a chance to learn how it all works, and experienced solvers an opportunity to show off. 

The Nation is both the oldest weekly news magazine in the country and the only US publication that features a weekly cryptic crossword. It has been shifting paradigms, broadening discourse, and instigating progress as an outspoken voice on politics and culture since 1865.
link_name: A puzzling celebration of The Nation's 150th anniversary

SOLD OUT. (A recording will be available on thenation.com.) The box office is keeping a wait-list and it's likely a few tickets will become available before the show due to cancellations.

Celebrating 150 Years of Dissent & Resistance 
with hosts Chris Hayes and Melissa Harris-Perry.

Featuring special guests Eve Ensler, Katrina vanden Heuvel, Tony Kushner, Bill McKibben, Kai Wright, Victor Navasky, Zephyr Teachout, Calvin Trillin, Mychal Denzel Smith and Laura Flanders.

Plus video clips from Barbara Kopple's film, Hot Type, and a live musical performance from the Brooklyn Youth Chorus.

All audience members will receive a free copy of The Nation's 268-page commemorative anniversary issue.

This event is presented by St. Ann's Warehouse, as part of The Nation magazine's 150th anniversary national tour. For a complete lineup of events across the US visit thenation.com/events

status_message:
In honor of The Nation magazine's 150th anniversary, The Commonwealth Club of California is proud to present a conversation with Van Jones, Katrina vanden Heuvel, Robert Reich, and Ai-jen Poo, moderated by Judge LaDoris Cordell (Ret.) 

Join us to discuss our country's inequality crisis--a core issue on which the magazine has long been sounding the alarm. 

﻿The wealth controlled by the top tenth of the top 1 percent has more than doubled over the past thirty years in the U.S., approaching unprecedented levels. What does this mean for the political process? The environment? Our civil society? Our civic culture? The future of our democracy? What can be done?

For tickets and more information, visit commonwealthclub.org/thenation150

This event is part of The Nation's 150th anniversary tour, including many events in the Bay Area and beyond. To learn more, visit thenation.com/events

Co-presented by The Nation and The Commonwealth Club of California.
link_name: Less Equal Than Ever?

status_message:
2015 marks the 150th anniversary of The Nation magazine, which was founded by abolitionists just months after the assassination of Abraham Lincoln. 

The Nation's publisher and editor, Katrina vanden Heuvel, Divest Harvard's founder, Chloe Maxmin, and The Nation's London correspondent, D.D. Guttenplan, will discuss Guttenplan's long-awaited book, The Nation: A Biography. 

The book chronicles the surprising story behind America's oldest weekly magazine—the bickering abolitionists who founded it; the campaigns, causes and controversies that shaped it; the rebels, mavericks and visionaries who have written, edited and fought in its pages for 150 years—and counting.

Tickets are just $5. Book sales and signing will follow. 

Brought to you by the Harvard Book Store.
link_name: The Nation's First 150 Years with Katrina vanden Heuvel, D.D. Guttenplan, and Chloe Maxmin

status_message:
The 12th Street Auditorium, The New School, NYC
66 West 12th Street, Manhattan

The year 2015 marks the 150th anniversary of The Nation Magazine. Join a conversation about The Nation's and the nation's past, present and future with Katrina vanden Heuvel, D.D. Guttenplan, Khalil Muhammad and Bob Herbert. Moderated by Laura Flanders.

Special comments from Mychal Denzel Smith, Sarah Leonard and Michelle Chen plus audience questions will follow the initial conversation.

The event is free of charge, but we expect to reach capacity. Please use this link to reserve your seat: https://americashiddenhistorynyc.eventbrite.com

Book sales and signing will follow the program. 

The story of The Nation is also the story of our country.  For the past 150 years, America's hidden history—of domestic oppression and overseas conquest, but also of opposition and resistance—has been recorded in the magazine's pages.  

Over the decades that opposition has had many names from the patrician reformers of the 1860s through a vast array of political and economic struggles to more recent fights against corporate globalization, free trade, economic inequality the destruction of the environment and police brutality.

Sponsored by The Nation & The New School.
link_name: America's Hidden History of Resistance

status_message:
Frances Fox Piven in Conversation with Christos Giovanopoulos

St. Joseph's College, Tuohy Hall Auditorium 

With Syriza on the ropes, and economic capitulation a looming possibility, what can the solidarity movement do to create a different future for Greece? What can American struggles for social justice learn from the horizontal, grassroots mutual aid model of Solidarity for All? 

Join this conversation between Christos Gianvanopoulos, a leader in the Solidarity movement and Frances Fox Piven, a preeminent American theorist of social movements. Audience questions will follow the discussion. 

Sponsored by The Nation, St. Joseph's College, Dissent and AKNY. Co-sponsored by Verso, Jacobin, Campaign for Peace and Democracy. This event is free and open to the public. Group drinks to follow, Brooklyn Public House, 247 DeKalb Avenue.
link_name: Austerity Is Killing Us: What the US is Learning from Greece's Fight

status_message: Absent a targeted intervention to bring black America into the current recovery, the teens who filled Baltimore's streets are unlikely to ever know a reality beyond crisis. Here's one of poverty's depressing truths: If you grow up a poor child, you are very likely to be a poor adult. And today, four out of 10 black children live in poverty—roughly double the national rate. Among the consequences of this fact is a generation of young people increasingly aware that their country does not, in fact, consider their lives important.

status_message: "It is clear that Detroit today is designing automobiles for style, cost, performance and calculated obsolescence, but not for safety. Doors that fly open on impact, inadequately secured seats, the sharp-edged rearview mirror, pointed knobs on instrument panel and doors, flying glass, the overhead structure—all illustrate the lethal potential of poor design. A sudden deceleration turns a steering wheel or a sharp-edged dashboard into a bone- and chest-crushing agent. Penetration of the shatterproof windshield can chisel one's head into fractions. The apparently harmless glove-compartment door has been known to unlatch under impact and guillotine a child. Automobiles are so designed as to be dangerous at any speed."—Ralph Nader for The Nation in 1959
link_name: This Is the Article That Launched the Consumer-Rights Movement

status_message: "Walking the sidewalks of my city in the morning, I dodge white dads' bikes daily, their little toddlers strapped into a back seat, and I don't mind as riding in the street or wide, traffic-filled avenues does seem a dangerous way to get to nursery school. Later in the morning, when I am still walking, the white fathers or mothers bike by me again, now with the back seats empty. I look around for police, wondering if there will be a ticketing for riding on the sidewalk, since no child's safety is at stake. No cops in sight. My great-nephew, young and black and not fully grown, was stopped and handcuffed by police a month ago for riding his bike on the sidewalk, his often glazed eyes glazing more deeply now."

status_message: Marshawn Lynch is financially forced by the league to talk to the media, ideally to mouth the same clichés every other player is hardwired to repeat. He spoke at the Super Bowl Media Day this week and 29 times repeated seven words that speak the truth of an NFL that demands players to double as corporate pitchmen: "I'm here so I won't get fined." If Lynch hadn't made an appearance, he would have faced a gobsmacking $500,000 fine. Roger Goodell, on the other hand, is under no obligation to talk to the public, even though he oversees a league that has received billions in corporate welfare and whose central office is designated by the federal government as a tax-free non-profit.
